title: 109_hr5149
content:
The Act is titled the "Eastern Sierra Rural Heritage and Economic Enhancement Act" and defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture or the Secretary of the Interior depending on the jurisdiction. It also includes the designation of wilderness areas. In California, certain areas are designated as wilderness areas under the Wilderness Act, including the Hoover wilderness addition in the Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest. This addition comprises approximately 39,680 acres and is part of the Hoover Wilderness designated by Public Law 88-577. The designation does not prevent the operation and maintenance of the existing historic Piute cabin. The Piute Cabin in the Hoover Wilderness Addition is to be maintained as it currently is, without restrictions on adjacent activities. Additionally, there is a proposed Emigrant Wilderness Addition in the Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest. The Hoover Proposed Wilderness Addition, depicted as Area D on a map dated August 8, 2005, is now part of the Emigrant Wilderness designated by Public Law 88-577. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION OF WILDERNESS AREAS. The wilderness areas designated by this Act will be managed by the Secretary in accordance with the Wilderness Act, with adjustments for effective date and jurisdiction. The Secretary must file a map and legal description of each wilderness area with the House Committee on Resources. The Secretary must file a map and legal description of each wilderness area with the House Committee on Resources and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate. The filed documents have the same legal force as the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. The maps and descriptions must be publicly available. Any land acquired within a designated wilderness area becomes part of that area and must be managed according to the Act. The Federal land designated as wilderness by this Act is withdrawn from various activities under public land laws, mining laws, and laws pertaining to mineral leasing. The Secretary may take measures for fire, insect, and disease management in designated wilderness areas. The Secretary must review existing policies for wilderness areas designated by the Act to ensure timely fire management responses. If deemed necessary, the installation and maintenance of hydrologic, meteorologic, or climatological instrumentation in wilderness areas are allowed for scientific and conservation purposes. The Act allows for the installation of instrumentation in wilderness areas for scientific purposes. It also permits military overflights, grazing of livestock, and maintenance of facilities in designated wilderness areas. The Act allows for management activities to maintain fish and wildlife populations in designated wilderness areas, as long as they comply with wilderness management plans and guidelines. State jurisdiction over fish and wildlife on public land in California is not affected by the Act. The Act does not create protective perimeters or buffer zones around wilderness areas. The Act does not create protective perimeters or buffer zones around wilderness areas. Non-wilderness activities or uses visible or audible from within a designated wilderness area shall not prevent their conduct outside the wilderness boundary. SEC. 5. WILD AND SCENIC RIVER DESIGNATION. Designation of the Amargosa Wild and Scenic River in California includes two segments: 
(A) 4.03 miles from the northern boundary of section 7 T21N R7E to 100 feet upstream of Tecopa Hot Springs road crossing, as a scenic river.
(B) 6.69 miles from 100 feet downstream of Tecopa Hot Springs Road crossing to 100 feet upstream of Old Spanish Trail Highway crossing near Tecopa, as a scenic river. The Amargosa River in California is designated as a wild and scenic river, with different segments designated for different uses. The segments include a scenic river from the northern boundary of section 16 to the Kingston Range Wilderness boundary, a wild river from the Kingston Range Wilderness boundary to the southern boundary of section 31, and a recreational river in between. Appropriations of $2,000,000 annually authorized for winter management of snowmobile use in areas adjacent to the Hoover Wilderness Addition in the Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest.
